fields.description:
There are some translation issues in Japanese environment. Please see below:

[Menu]
"Check for Update..." = "アップデートを確認"
"Install Command Line Tool" = "コマンドラインツールをインストール"
"SourceTree Website..." = "SourceTree の Web サイト..."
"Atlassian Website..." = "Atlassian の Web サイト..."
"Bookmark Open Repositories..." = "開いているリポジトリをブックマーク..."
"Add Remote..." = "リモートを追加..."
"Open in Terminal" = "ターミナルで開く"
"Continue [Action]" = "継続 [アクション]"
"Abort [Action]" = "中止 [アクション]"

[Preferences - General]
"Terminal App" = "ターミナルアプリ"
"Language" = "言語"
"Always display full console output" = "すべてのコンソール出力を常に表示する"

[Preferences - Diff]
"Ignore File Patterns" = "無視ファイルのパターン:"

[Preferences - Mercurial]
"Use Graft instead of Transplant if available" = "利用可能なら、Transplant ではなく Graft を使用"

[Preferences - Git]
"Push all tags to remotes" = "リモートへタグをすべてプッシュする"

[Preferences - Custom Action]
"Custom Actions Defined:" = "カスタムアクションの定義:"

[Repository view - Settings - Remotes]
"Remote name:" = "リモートの名前"
"Default remote" = "デフォルトにする"
"URL / path:" = "URL / パス:"

[Repository view - Settings - Advanced]
"Advanced" = "高度な設定"
"Commit Text Replacement" = "コミット文字列の置換"

"Replacement Type:" = "置換タイプ:"
"Project Prefix:" = "プロジェクトプレフィックス"
"Hosting URL:" = "ホスティング URL:"
"Other" = "その他"
fields.summary: Japanese translation issues

fields.description:
Perforce is adding some interesting new DVCS-like features in their about-to-be-released p4sandbox local server. The P4v GUI client is pretty awful, however.

Since I'm compelled to use the big central server at my workplace, any chance you could give p4sandbox some UI love?
fields.summary: Support for p4sandbox

fields.description: Validation appears to be incorrect and is checking whether it's the current revision, not whether it's the uncommitted line.
fields.summary: Mercurial strip disabled on latest commit when no uncommitted line

fields.description:
It'd be great if one could have the functionality of "hg strip" and its git equivalent (if any) exposed via GUI.

In 1.2 there is an unused "Remove" button in the toolbar while viewing commit logs for both Mercurial and Git. It might be reusable for deleting previous commits.
fields.summary: Deleting previous commits with git and hg

fields.description:
See https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/25836/mercurial-wrong-changeset-in-bold-after-pull

SourceTree is bolding the latest revision on the active branch, which isn't necessarily the one that the user has checked out. This may only occur when a new head is pulled, before the view is closed and re-opened, according to the person reporting this.
fields.summary: Wrong log line bolded when Mercurial has multiple heads

fields.description:
Raised at https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-51

For Git there is a particular case where the log updates, but the pull/push badges do not; this is because essentially the pull/push badges are caching the last fetch / push until the next remote refresh. The log update is detected differently to the badges just because the badges *usually* require a remote request to change, compared to the log which can refresh locally. Maybe try to short-circuit the badge update for at least Git in this scenario, because if the fetch has already occurred you have all the information you need (unlike Mercurial which will still need a remote request).
fields.summary: Detect external pull/push and update incoming / outgoing badges earlier

fields.description:
Running Jonathon Fowler's Mac port of Ken Silverman's pngout lossless compression utility over the SourceTree.app image resources saves about 400kB in the application bundle.

The Mac port can be found here: http://www.jonof.id.au/kenutils and a list of the savings is attached.
fields.summary: Image resources can be reduced by ~400kB by using pngout

fields.description:
To reproduce:
1. Go to Repository -> Push for a git repository.
2. Look at the table of branches.
3. Double click on names of the remote branches. Notice that they are editable. I would not expect them to be.

If this is intended behavior, then I think the operation to push to a newly named branch should be explicit, and done one branch at a time, not in a table like this. This feels like a bug and makes it too easy to accidentally modify branch names.
fields.summary: Items in branch push table for git are editable
Add services menu integration to go with command line tool

fields.description:
When a diff gets suppressed the app displays a "diff suppressed" message. I would like a way to temporarily override the diff size limit and force the display of the diff.

The workaround is to open the preferences and raise the limit, then afterwards go back and lower it again. It would be great if I could just hit a button and force the display of the diff, mostly so I can do single-line staging.
fields.summary: Button to override diff suppression limit

fields.description:
While becoming familiar with the Source Tree interface and Git, I accidentally "reverted" an old commit which immediately created a new commit. I was unable to find any way to "delete" or undo this commit.

Using Tower, I was able to right click on an older commit and select "Rollback to this commit", which I believe moves the branch pointer to the older commit, leaving the newer commit inaccessible and thus it disappears from the history (I presume it will be garbage collected in the future).

I think the equivalent CLI command is something like `git reset --hard <commit>`.

Adding to the confusion was Source Tree's "reset" button in the toolbar. This appeared to be greyed out most of the time. Eventually I figured out that Source Tree's "reset" appears to be for undoing local modifications (similar to `svn revert`).

I realise that Source Tree is designed to work with not only Git, and that there may be some clash with terminology. Perhaps the function of the "reset" button could be clarified somehow, though. And I would like to see a new feature added that would allow me to "rollback" to an older commit, similar to Tower.
fields.summary: Add ability to move branch pointer to commit in Git repositories.

fields.description:
Raised here: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-54

If you have a lot of submodules, even on Git the recursive check can get slow? You can turn it off in Git, but not Mercurial. 

It would probably be a good idea to cache the status to speed things up. However, knowing when to refresh the cache reliably might be tricky.
fields.summary: Cache the submodule status to speed up commit & push checks

fields.description: Seems to be when there are uncommitted changes previously, then they are committed (or maybe reverted), and it mistakenly thinks the first line is the uncommitted changes line still, because Backout etc are disabled.
fields.summary: Log view context menu items disabled on first row sometimes

fields.description:
Add CodebaseHQ as a Hosted Project provider.

https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/22770/codebase-sourcetree

API: http://docs.atechmedia.com/codebase/developer-api
fields.summary: Hosted Project - CodebaseHQ

fields.description:
As reported here: https://skitch.com/chrisyip/g1exa/sourcetree-ui-issue

I've seen this happen on occasion with the annotations too, particularly with submodules. Resizing the sidebar usually sorts it out. I've tried before to get to the bottom of this but the view setup seems correct; it's as if the sizing hierarchy gets out of step somehow.
fields.summary: Long branch names can cause the right-aligned elements in the sidebar to crop

fields.description: I noticed that the "background.png" icon is visible above the DMG background image.
fields.summary: background.png is visible on DMG installer

fields.description:
It's more than doubled, most of it in the libexec area; git-http-push and others are now 1.7MB each rather than 500K as they were in previous versions.

Is there anything we can do about that?
fields.summary: Git install seems to have grown very big
Create separate downloadable command-line tool installer for App Store version

fields.description: See https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/15005/how-can-i-do-git-svn-dcommit-on-a-single-branch . Configuring them in .git/config's svn-remote apparently works with Tower / GitX.
fields.summary: Git-svn doesn't display all branches when they're configured?

fields.description:
When initiating a merge via SourceTree GUI (e.g. right click on master and select merge master into topic), a confirmation dialogue pops up asking if you are sure you want to merge.

This dialogue would be a great place to add options and arguments to the git command that will be executed (and also preview - to make sure what you think you are doing is what you are actually doing), and perhaps also an option to show the transcript (and keep it open until dismissed).

This would allow things like `git merge --squash`. This could apply to many other options as well, e.g. `reset --soft`.

The option to show the transcript (and keep it open until dismissed) would be helpful because at the moment, it seems the only way to access this is to quickly (before the command finishes) click on a small triangle, which will display progress and remain open. If the command finishes quickly, the window is dismissed before you can see the actual command that was run or the results.

I'm trying to learn Git at the moment (coming from SVN), and a lot of workflow guides include commands with arguments and options that I can't seem to do through SourceTree. It would also greatly help new users learn what SourceTree is doing and how to use Git if we could preview the actual commands to be executed before, and see the results after.

Finally, and this could be a separate issue, I found the `rebase...` context menu confusing. When I am checked out and I select `rebase...` on the current branch, or another branch, what is actually going to happen? Other commands have more explicit descriptions such as "merge master into topic".
fields.summary: Expose command line options and arguments in confirmation dialogues

fields.description:
If the script is deleted or somehow the path is wrong, the task will fail with 'launch path not accessible'.

Need to handle that gracefully.
fields.summary: Creating a custom action which references an invalid command causes exception

fields.description:
As requested in follow-up to SRCTREE-658

Because it's useful to have commands defined once and available for all repositories, this is best implemented as a per-repo filter. When defining a command there should be an option for it to be included or excluded in repositories by default.
fields.summary: Allow custom actions to be filtered per repository

fields.description: As requested in follow-up to SRCTREE-658
fields.summary: Add keyboard shortcut option to custom actions

fields.description: Hi Atlassian! I would like to voice my desire to see support for mercurial queues in the SourceTree project. I apologize if this is a duplicate but I have not found a related bug/feature. I noticed that this feature is on your websites road map under the "In a while" heading, and though willing to wait, I would like to voice my interest in this particular feature being completed soon. Its implementation would help my use of SourceTree and solidify its position on my desktop. Thanks
fields.summary: Mercurial Queues Extension ( hg mq )

fields.description:
When using the internal diff to view changes it would be useful to have an option to see the entire contents of a file, rather than being limited to 100 lines of context.  Sometimes a piece of code related to a given change is outside the range of 100 lines, and it would be nice to be able to switch to see the entire file contents, as is possible in the Fisheye diff viewer.

In addition, it's convenient to be able to use the File Status / Working Copy view as a quick, light code browser.  However, when viewing file contents, larger files are cut off after 100 lines, so that either Quick Look or another editor has to be launched to see the full source.
fields.summary: Add "Full" diff context option for showing complete file source

fields.description:
A command line tool for viewing a repository would be great. Personally, I would like this command to not attempt to add a bookmark for the repository (like git tower does.)

I'd love to cd into any sub-folder of a project folder, type sourcetree (or something), and have it open that repository and not attempt to create a bookmark.


The product looks great so far.
fields.summary: Command line tool

fields.description:
If you're working with a very large changeset, and decide to stash the changes in GIT; viewing the large stash in Sourcetree will make the UI laggy and unresponsive.

As I understand it an stash is more or less an GIT commit object:
http://www.quora.com/How-does-git-stash-work

Perhaps we shouldn't just load the entire object into Sourcetree?
fields.summary: Viewing large GIT stashes shouldn't crash SourceTree

fields.description:
I have a lot of projects in SVN and I want to switch to Git and SourceTree. I need to try Git and SourceTree first, though, so that I can plan the migration process and become familiar enough to help others in the team during the transition period.

When cloning an SVN repository, there is no option to specify an SVN authors file. I also tried setting svn.authorsfile globally for the system and embedded versions of Git, without any success.

I would like to see the option to set the svn.authorsfile config globally and also for individual projects when cloning an SVN repository. The per-project option could go in the "Advanced Options" section of the Clone Repository dialogue.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Allow svn.authorsfile config to be set globally and for individual projects when cloning an SVN repository (in the advanced options?)

fields.description:
While viewing a Git log with "Uncommitted changes" selected, "Add" button should add files. With Mercurial, it isn't as essential since there isn't a staging area, but it would still be nice when there are untracked files.

Comment from Steve Streeting:
"there isn't room on the log view for a staging view though"

I don't really need to view staging from that location. But, any modifications made to the repository are shown in "Uncomitted changes"'s changed files tableview anyway, so a column could be shown displaying staged content. Or a checkbox to toggle between staged and all changes. Or the icons of the staged files could be slightly different from the unstaged files (for example, a blue circle in the background).

In any case, it's strange that the "Add" button which could be pretty functional here does not actually work.
fields.summary: "Add" button in the Log view for Uncomitted changes should work just like on Working Copy view.

fields.description:
{{git log}} shows the AuthorDate rather than the CommitDate, -so SourceTree should probably do the same-.

The AuthorDate differs from the CommitDate when a commit is cherry-picked or a branch is rebased. For example, {{git log --format=fuller}} shows the following for a commit that I cherry-picked the following day:

{noformat}
Author:     Chris Bandy <cbandy@sittercity.com>
AuthorDate: Wed Nov 30 14:19:19 2011 -0600
Commit:     Chris Bandy <cbandy@sittercity.com>
CommitDate: Thu Dec 1 20:52:35 2011 -0600
{noformat}

-Also, I think the CommitDate matches the ancestry of a branch, making it largely uninformative in the Log View and file log.-

When the CommitDate differs from the AuthorDate, it may be good to display both in the commit details/summary.
fields.summary: Show AuthorDate rather than CommitDate

fields.description:
SourceTree mostly provides a (nice) front end to git commands that are simple enough from the CLI.  An example where it adds value is editing hunks in the index.   Another place that a GUI would be especially helpful would be in handling git rebase --interactive, where I currently have to use a combination of emacs and SourceTree to choose which changesets I want to merge.

I can think of various UI approaches this this, but I'm sure that you can come up with better ones!  The desideratum would be clearly identifying the content of each merged changeset, with the adopted (and editable) login messages.
fields.summary: Support git rebase --interactive

fields.description: If you have a name which is both a git tag and name, command line git merge produces a helpful message but SourceTree silently accepts the default resolution (the tag).  This is very unhelpful if you are unaware of the ambiguity; SourceTree should display the warning dialogue
fields.summary: When merging a name which is both a git tag and a git branch, SourceTree silently chooses the former

fields.description:
This is what my working directory contains:
{code}
Ajay-Sridhars-MacBook-Pro-2:kiln asridhar$ du -sh ../kiln
625M    ../kiln
Ajay-Sridhars-MacBook-Pro-2:kiln asridhar$ find . | wc -l
   18628
Ajay-Sridhars-MacBook-Pro-2:kiln asridhar$ ls
apache-tomcat-5.5.26            apache-tomcat-6.0.18
apache-tomcat-5.5.26 copy       apache-tomcat-6.0.18 copy
apache-tomcat-5.5.26 copy 2     apache-tomcat-6.0.18 copy 2
apache-tomcat-5.5.26 copy 3     apache-tomcat-6.0.18 copy 3
apache-tomcat-5.5.26 copy 4     apache-tomcat-6.0.18 copy 4
apache-tomcat-5.5.26 copy 5     apache-tomcat-6.0.18 copy 5
apache-tomcat-5.5.26 copy 6     apache-tomcat-6.0.18 copy 6
apache-tomcat-5.5.26 copy 7     apache-tomcat-6.0.18 copy 7
{code}
If I try to add, then commit the changeset from Sourcetree it takes hours - I let it running for 2 hours and it still didn't finish :(

However from command line it takes minutes.
fields.summary: Slow performance when adding/commiting large changeset with lots of files to Kiln/HG repository

fields.description:
When a remote repository is responding slowly (e.g., SourceForge), it takes several seconds for the Git Pull dialog to present the remote branch selection. However, most of the time the remote branches remain the same, so it would be OK to immediately present a cached list of branches. The remote repository can then be checked in the background and the list be updated when the data is ready.

This would make it much faster to do a simple pull, as the previously used remote branch could be offered right away as the default option (or the git config option "pull.default" could be used).

With the current version, I typically do "git pull" from a terminal because it works so much faster, even though I use SourceTree for working with my repository.
fields.summary: Git pull: Cache remote branch names

fields.description:
Reported here: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-44

Changes in the working copy are omitted from the diff. This works properly in git.
fields.summary: Hg: Selecting working copy & other revision in the log omits working copy changes

fields.description:
If a commit has an multi-line display there is no indication that there is more than one line when viewing the graph browser for HG Repo.
However, the graph view shows all commit lines for GIT Repo
fields.summary: Multiline Commits aren't displayed in Graph View for hg

fields.description:
I quite frequently add a file hunk by hunk to the staging area. With GitX for example the button to "stage" will always be at the top right and when I click it the button for the next hunk will move there.

In Sourcetree however the buttons are at the bottom of the hunk so after every click of "Stage Hunk" I have to scroll around to find the next one. It would be much more convenient to have the buttons at the top of each hunk.
fields.summary: "Hunk" specific buttons at the top so they keep positions

fields.description: Optimisation - since the Jump List on the Log View isn't used that much, it's a waste to spend time updating it every time. Instead, just populate the top option (SHA) and populate the rest when dropping-down.
fields.summary: Populate the 'Jump' list on demand instead of every refresh

fields.description:
git reset --hard for checked-out branch
git branch -f for non checked out branches

GitX allows you to drag / drop branch badges, might be a nice way to implement it.
fields.summary: Support moving branch pointers in Git

fields.description:
It would be nice to be able to create a patch from a GIT stash through the UI. Either by right clicking on a stash and saying "Save as patch" or by selecting "Create Patch" and select "Patch From Stash".

This can sort of be achieved by applying the stash however it would be good to be able to directly create a patch from the stash.
fields.summary: Support for creating a patch from a stash

fields.description:
See https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/19029/listing-of-revisions-is-very-slow

I can't recreate this, might need to go to 10.6 to do so. Doesn't seem related to the change to the 10.7 SDK, and yet changes in 1.2.9.1 are not major, and speed is the same here.
fields.summary: Some users reporting slowdown between 1.2.8.1 and 1.2.9

fields.description:
To allow people to solve this issue without editing .gitconfig: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/SOURCETREEKB/UTF-8+Characters+Show+in+SourceTree+as+Escaped+Character+Codes

This will be necessary when running in a sandbox anyway.
fields.summary: Add Git quotepaths option to Preferences

fields.description: Check from Address Book for a contact with the same email in order to display commiter picture/avatar before checking from gravatar site
fields.summary: Use address book to check for user image
Can't commit to GIT repo if the file path contains accented characters

fields.description: It would be nice if SourceTree supported repositories hosted on an instance of github:enterprise with an arbitrary URL.  Assuming the APIs are consistent, this might be as simple as allowing the URL to be specified when adding a github account.
fields.summary: Add support for repos hosted on github:enterprise (github:fi)

fields.description: There's no way to change the order of the actions in the menu right now, support manual re-ordering so user can customise their menu better.
fields.summary: Allow Custom Actions to be re-ordered

fields.description:
On SourceTree 1.2.8.1 the Spelling and Grammer preference is remembered and honored:
http://screencast.com/t/nhU5uQ7oli

However on SourceTree 1.2.9.1 the if you ask SourceTree to not {{Correct Speling Automatically}} SourceTree forgets the preference and commits autocorrects words:
http://screencast.com/t/RllqjbGL
fields.summary: Can't disable Spelling auto-correction in Snow Leopard

fields.description:
In our company we use a lot of solutions of yours: jira, confluence, crowd, fisheye and now we are taking look at the source tree: our first look was great, but one small thing blocks us from using it at the end: no support for submodules.

In our projects we have currently 5-6 submodules linked. For us it's important to know which of them have the right version checked-out as for the commit in the umbrella project. So beside displaying all submodules, their status, some other minor stuff would be appreciated: update submodule, update all of them, initialize them. Having this feature, I'll make sure the whole team of ours (20 ppl) will use source tree instead of GitX (modified especially by us by adding submodules support) or Tower.
fields.summary: Add support for submodules

fields.description:
It would be nice to pick out JIRA and Fisheye issue numbers in the log descriptions and hyperlink them to the correct webpages.

The best way to do this would be to have repository-level configurable Regexps which transform matching patterns (e.g. SRCTREE-9999) into hyperlinks with provided URL stubs. There's no reason this has to be just JIRA etc, any pattern should be matchable, but let's add a shortcut for JIRA/Fisheye issues that pre-populates the Regexp with something reasonable.
fields.summary: Hyperlink JIRA, Fisheye and other matched patterns

fields.description:
The graft extension brings cherry picking to mercurial. 
I need that because I don't want to place all change lists from my development branch on the release branch.

http://www.selenic.com/mercurial/hg.1.html#graft
fields.summary: Please support Mercurial 2.0 with graft extension

fields.description:
I have been trying out SourceTree and MacHg clients to view/access my Mercurial repositories, and each has features I like, but neither has all. One of the features I like in MacHg that SourceTree doesn't appear to have is a real-time/incremental search/filter box above the history list (eg. maybe to the left of "Jump to:" drop-down), to filter the history as-you-type.

Can you add something like this in SoureTree.
fields.summary: Incremental/real-time search filter box of history, like MacHg

fields.description: Support for nested repositories: these are submodules in git and subrepos in hg.
fields.summary: Submodules / subrepositories

fields.description: It would be nice to have bazaar supported for SourceTree. Bazaar is a very smart VCS, the only problem for us is there isn't any good client for Mac OS, which makes it hard to use. The bazaar explorer e.g. is very user unfriendly and it sometimes does not really work. Besides, the IDE integration of bazaar has been very limited, so it would be nice to have a great tool like SourceTree as a client.
fields.summary: bazaar support

fields.description:
I would really love the ability to select multiple files and ignore them all by exact match. I run into this often when setting up a new tool for a project; Unity3D is particularly egregious about generating loads of files for every new asset.

Currently, my workaround is to add them to .hgignore or .gitignore manually, but it would be so much easier to select them right in the SourceTree UI and hit "Ignore...".

Thanks!
fields.summary: Ability to ignore multiple exact filenames

fields.description: http://mercurial.selenic.com/wiki/LargefilesExtension
fields.summary: Mercurial 2.0 large files extension support

fields.description:
When reviewing commits in the Log View, right-clicking a file in the commit details pane allows you to see the Log or Blame of the file, but only for the history of your current working copy.

Log and Blame should show the history up to and including the commit you have selected.
fields.summary: In Log View, Log Selected and Blame Selected should use the selected revision

fields.description:
It would be great if git SHA1 hashes were active/hot in the commit message. Clicking a hash would do something related to the current view.

For example, in our repository we have messages like "This reverts <sha1>". I often use the Log View to review commits, and being able to jump to that commit in a single click would be very helpful. Some kind of popup when hovering could also be helpful.

Last I checked, QGit4 replaced both full and partial hashes with all or part of the first line of the commit message as a link.
fields.summary: Link to revisions from the commit message

fields.description: Requested by a user to avoid having to open the main repo window to see what branch they're on.
fields.summary: Display current branch on bookmarks summary entry

fields.description:
Step to repro:
1. Open a repo with some activity
2. Click Search view
3. Search for a valid SHA (either long or short, using any type: User, Commit Message, File Changes)

Actual: No results appear in the search.
Expected: Valid matches should appear.
fields.summary: Search should display results for SHA matches

fields.description:
As discussed at support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/suggestions/181-custom-external-actions it should be possible to launch external scripts against arbitrary files.

This enables users such as myself who are developing in non-native environments to automate their workflow (eg: developing software for arbitrary non-native platforms, using virtual machine instances or emulators to perform code deployment and testing).

This is a HUGELY IMPORTANT feature for me and I have patiently waited months for its implementation with no news so far...
fields.summary: Custom External Actions

fields.description: Please provide full-screen Lion support.
fields.summary: Full-screen Lion support

fields.description:
The sidebar seems to use a bold font on the wrong branch - it should be the same branch as the one with the 'current branch' icon, but it often appears on another branch.

This was raised on Twitter against 1.2.9 but in fact it occurs on earlier versions too.
fields.summary: Current branch bold font is off-by-one in sidebar

fields.description: The JIRA issue tracker has an extremely poor user-experience, for example it is very difficult to effectively search existing issues and quite inconvenient when submitting new issues.  It would be wonderful if the Source Tree product could use something that is more user friendly.
fields.summary: better issue tracker

fields.description: While developing I spend most of my time in the "working copy" view, with "Flat" and "Show Pending" selected.  When I want to view the commit log or annotate a file, I need to switch to "column" or "tree" view and "Show All."  It is wonderful to have these different view options, but it would be significantly better if I could press one button (or open a new window) to browse the project so I can log / annotate files.
fields.summary: quick switch to file browse mode or separate browser window
Use tildes in config paths where possible

fields.description:
Raised as https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-24

{quote}My core.excludesfile is set to ~/.gitignore, and when I try and use SourceTree's "Edit File" button it just logs this to the console:

10/28/11 1:54:53.547 PM SourceTree: LSOpenFromURLSpec() returned -43 for application TextEdit path ~/.gitignore.

It really needs to expand tildes in the path before trying to open it.
{quote}
fields.summary: Expand tildes in path when trying to edit global ignore list

fields.description: A few people have asked about how to switch back to English instead of the localised versions which are used automatically (standard OS X language choice). So far the advice is that you can switch it in your overall system prefs, or run SourceTree via Language Switcher or similar. But it would be nice to give the option to switch in the Preferences.
fields.summary: Allow people to override the language choice in Preferences

fields.description: When I want to create a new repository, sourcetree defaults to creating a HG repo; then, I have to select a git one. This should be configurable or be the last used.
fields.summary: HG is not my default new repository type. It's git.

fields.description: A really nifty feature that bazaar explorer has is the ability to auto complete the filenames in the repo that you have while typing them out in the commit message area.
fields.summary: Auto complete filenames in commit messages

fields.description:
When selecting a previously created shelf, there is no command in the application's menus to unshelve, only a contextual menu on the shelf itself.

Please add an unshelve command to the menus.

(Also I reckon the command should be spelled "un-shelve" with a hyphen. I don't think "unshelve" has passed into English dictionaries at this time. Having said that my dictionary is a few years older than it should be... as am I.)
fields.summary: Add 'unshelve' menu command

fields.description:
See https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/17004/multiple-instances-of-p4merge

p4merge ends up launching multiple instances. You can prevent this by using the 'launchp4merge' script instead of 'p4merge', but unfortunately that doesn't work when you call it directly. It appears you need to call it via another wrapper script which includes the hard-coded path. This is awkward when the location of p4merge may not be predeterminable, may need to create a wrapper script on demand in App Support.
fields.summary: Launch p4merge via a wrapper script to avoid multiple instances

fields.description:
I've been adding more functionality to the file section of the log view for people who use that view most of the time and have the uncommitted line selected, but adding more is going to get too cluttered. 

Should switch menus entirely between the uncommitted line and the regular commit lines, it will make more sense and free up space for enabled items. Will need to refactor some of the validation to be more shared. 

Staging / unstaging should not be attempted though, there isn't enough room.
fields.summary: Make file context menu different for uncommitted changes line in log view

fields.description: Right now when you switch branches in git, if you have outstanding change you have to stash them. It would nice to support the '-m' option to Git checkout as an extra checkbox, in addition to the 'discard local changes' option.
fields.summary: Support -m option to git checkout when switching branches

fields.description:
As a gui issue, sourcetree is unresponsive when I open a working tree with lots of files. I neither get an estimation of when it finishes loading the tree or the instant query of the top level folder. 

I generalized the issue because it happens to both `show pending` and `show all`.
fields.summary: Opening a reasonably large folder with lots of files appears to give no result

fields.description:
Add a new button to the 'Mercurial Version' and 'Git Version' sections in preferences to allow the user to manually specify where the system version should be taken from. 

Add a path field to the view to show where it's being taken from currently, if set to system.
fields.summary: Add user manual override to locate system git / hg

fields.description: I have git installed with the OSX installer. It puts it into /usr/local/git/bin and that is on my PATH first. When I select 'Use System Git', it finds some other version of git. Ideally, I'd be able to specify the version of git that is on my PATH.
fields.summary: finding and using the right installed version of git

fields.description:
I have a lot of favourited repos on github and bitbucket, such that my "Hosted Repositories" screen takes way too long to navigate. Usually I'm only interested in my repos, so a simple filter to show only my own accounts would be great.

Sorting by owner isn't great because I'm not at the top, and I have different account names on github vs. bitbucket.
fields.summary: Should have a filter on the Hosted Repositories screen to show only my accounts

fields.description:
You can't currently search for the content of changed files in the search pane on a Mercurial repo (pickaxe search in Git, which is supported). This has so far been because the output of 'hg grep' is awkward to parse reliably.

Logging this so that we can come back to it later and hopefully find a way to make it work.
fields.summary: Support hg grep

fields.description:
Right now when you right-click a local branch and select 'Push' to the tracked item, you can't confirm the resulting dialog until the remote refresh of branches is complete. 

Because this is a tracked branch, there's actually no need to see the other remote branches and also no reason to prevent the confirmation of the dialog until that's complete. Pushing just based on the local tracking information is enough. This would save a few seconds.

Also applies to pull.
fields.summary: Git push/pull via sidebar context on tracked branch should skip remote refresh

fields.description: I hadn't intended to support Lion's fullscreen mode until there was the option to switch repositories within the same window, but a couple of users have requested that it is added earlier.
fields.summary: Lion fullscreen support

fields.description: Have to be careful when fixing this to specifically detect the change in file selection, since refreshes triggered by file changes etc should preserve the scroll bar position.
fields.summary: When switching between files in the log view, scroll bar of the diff pane should reset to the top

fields.description:
Originally raised here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/15201/using-sourcetree-on-a-local-apache-server-the-certificate-is-getting-rejected-despite-being-accepted-in-the-keychain

While SourceTree does supply the web.cacerts option if the user hasn't specified it, it appears some people are finding that the fingerprint needs to be supplied in the .hgrc too. SourceTree should make this easier to set up. MacHg prompts for this apparently.
fields.summary: Support self-signed certificates better by prompting for fingerprint acceptance

fields.description:
Raised originally here: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-8

Right now if either the primary tool, or any helper tools on which that depends, is located in a non-standard path, SourceTree will just reject the tool. Should allow a fallback for the user to specify the location.
fields.summary: Prompt for external diff/merge tool locations if not found in typical locations

fields.description:
It would be nice to be able to use the 'record' extension to commit hunks or lines in Mercurial (a bit like Git staging except we go straight to commit).
http://mercurial.selenic.com/wiki/RecordExtension

The problem is that the record extension interface is currently entirely based on an interactive terminal. In order to support it, we need a full command-line interface. This will probably require a fork or re-implementation of the record extension.
fields.summary: Support record extension

fields.description:
See https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/14932/using-proxies-with-sourcetree

Right now you need to manually configure them in .hgrc and .gitconfig, it would be better to have an option in Preferences which sets both.
fields.summary: Auto-configure or unify proxy settings for Git & Hg

fields.description:
It would be useful to be able to push to multiple remotes at once. This has been requested a couple of times now.

Affects:
* Push option in commit dialog
* Push dialog itself
fields.summary: Push to multiple remotes

fields.description:
Hi there,
When making a Git commit, SourceTree presents the option to push the change immediately to a remote ("Push commits immediately to: ")

However, this pushes all branches. It'd be better if it only pushed the current branch by default, since there can often be non-fast-forward updates on other branches which cause this command to fail.

Thanks for a fantastic product.

Regards,

Graeme
fields.summary: Pushing while committing should only push to current branch by default (Git)

fields.description:
When pushing to a remote, SourceTree includes the --tags option. This isn't always ideal, and there doesn't seem to be a way to disable it.

Ideally, pushing to a remote would not, by default, push tags, but instead offer a checkbox allowing this. The checkbox could be 'sticky', so that the user's preference is remembered and activated next time.

Keep up the good work.

Regards,

Graeme
fields.summary: Pushing should not push tags by default - instead offer checkbox. (Git)

fields.description: Please expose the "git branch -m old_branch new_branch" functionality to easily rename a branch within SourceTree.
fields.summary: Ability to rename a branch

fields.description: One user found it awkward to differentiate between stashes, requested this.  Not sure why they just couldn't name them more uniquely!  http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/problems/458-display-stash-timestamp
fields.summary: Extra information on stashes

fields.description: Would be nice to be able to search inside the inline diff view.  http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/problems/457-find-in-inline-diff-view
fields.summary: Search within diff view

fields.description: So long as the text hasn't been changed since entering the dialog.
fields.summary: Default the commit text to previous commit if Amend checked

fields.description: External diff isn't that useful on a conflicted file, so maybe change it to 'Visual Merge' when selecting conflicts?  The problem is what to do when a mixture of file statuses are selected.
fields.summary: Change 'External Diff' button to 'Visual Merge' on conflicted file?

fields.description: Git has a limit of 4096 arguments, excessively long lines seems to make Hg choke too. Probably need to split file list.
fields.summary: Commit screen hangs with too many files added

fields.description: http://support.sourcetreeapp.com/discussions/problems/408-answering-basic-questions-about-remote-branch-history  More general filtering options on the log?
fields.summary: See the list of commits that you'll get by merging

fields.description: From Mike Cannon-Brooks: he finds it confusing that the default selection in the combo box in git commit is set based on whether you're using the staging area or not. He would prefer if it remembered the last option that you used.  It seems more sensible to me to use the mode which most reflects the file status view you've been using, but maybe give the option to behave otherwise? Or perhaps default to the view appropriate to the staging view being enabled or not when you change the option in Preferences, but then after that remember the last used option?
fields.summary: Default the git commit dialog to staged / all based on last used mode

fields.description: Requested by @lucasmeijer: filter the graph view in various ways, for example 'show commits not in headA and headB'.  Useful for integrating feature branches into mainstream and other things.
fields.summary: Filtering in the log view

fields.description: You can look this up on the API. Might be useful?
fields.summary: Automatically add fork origin as a remote on GH/BB projects?

fields.description:
From Walter Stanish:

{quote}
I have spent a day reviewing six or seven OSX GUIs with git support. Yours is by far the most mature - congratulations on a great piece of software in a challenging area. Fantastique :) However, there is something missing!

I will immediately buy this product if you add the following critical feature for me... custom external actions!

The rationale for this requirement is as follows: my main project right now is a script that is a heavily Linux kernel-version-linked. Other people have made various forks of this, and I need a GUI to easily automate my workflow, accomplish push/pull requests and most importantly testing. I run Linux in VMWare VMs. I need to ability to rapidly deploy code to a VM, run tests against it, and see the results. An arbitrary "launch external script against this revision" option would allow me to implement all that I need, and other SourceTree users could also use the feature to solve any similar development environment integration issues.

I do not work with a fully fledged IDE (I am a 'vi' user and this is my first ever Mac ... <3 months old) so the ability to launch scripts from the GUI to facilitate testing and other external actions against revisions (and optionally also files) would be a "deal closer" for my purchase. In addition, I promise to becoming a raving fan and tell all my friends :)

Thoughts on such a feature follow.

For my immediate purposes, it would be enough to have a single external script execute against an entire revision of a branch. The only argument would need to be the directory in which the revision was presently hosted. (The user could configure this in preferences: a textbox with "eg: /path/to/your/tool ${REV_LOC}" and a second textbox 'Name of Action' would suffice as a minimalist configuration UI). However, it would be nice to be able to define multiple actions.

To take the idea a step further it may be nice do define one or more actions of this sort that can be executed against individual file(s) within a revision of a branch instead of against an entire revision (So I could define 'Edit with vim', 'Calculate line count', 'Show checksums', etc.). In fact, the latter two would make excellent examples which could be disabled by default (Maybe the checksums option being powered by a simple bundled example script showing md5/shasum/cksum binaries' generated hashes for the file in a terminal window).

Further implementation considerations.

Per action 'Output type' dropdown....
- Option to show terminal output for non-interactive console-type tools in a window that is embedded within a popup managed by SourceTree itself (This is a user interface nicety, as it prevents the user having to "apple-Q but wonder if other terminals are open", or "apple-W and then apple-tab back to SourceTree" ... instead they can just apple-W to close the window.) - Option not to show terminal output at all (just launch the process and forget about it) - Option to launch the process in a real Terminal window (a nicety vs. users having to figure out how to do this via the command line)

Per action hotkey support:
- It would be insanely cool to be able to apple-V for me to deploy and perform automated testing against a branch revision on a VM, shift-apple-R to do a full regression test on a branch revision through a series of VMs running different historic kernels, apple-E to edit in vi, shift-apple-D to deploy the current branch revision to a VM ready for manual testing, etc.

Possible extra features:
- An option for storing the above preferences either on a project or installation-wide basis. - An option to filter 'file'-linked external actions by file type (for example as determined by libmagic, eg: with a regex match on the output of 'file -I ')

Existing options thoughts:
You have 'Open' and 'Quick Look' options now. My project includes shell scripts intended to be run as root and perform serious base system modification under Linux - not good to 'Open' by accident on OSX :) 'Quick Look' shows no useful info for such files.

GUI thoughts:
Branch revision linked actions could be accessible with either a right-click on the revision and the name of the external action being visible, or a hotkey when the revision was selected.
File-linked actions could be accessible with either right-click on the file and the name of the external action being visible, or a hotkey when the file was selected.
Having written the above, I do realise that it is not good to bloat software with other actions - "do one thing and do it well", and that SourceTree is not an IDE. However, by adding features such as those described above and having them turned off by default (ie: average user sees zero changes until enabling them explicitly in preferences), more advanced users can use SourceTree effectively as an IDE, and normal users will see no interface bloat at all. Therefore the value of your already excellent software is increased and it becomes attractive to a wider market - and as a potential replacement for more expensive IDEs.

So I think that, commercially and technically, this is a really good feature set for you consider adding.

Thanks for your consideration in this matter. Remember, a minimal implementation of the above will see my immediate purchase and infinite happiness, plus probably some purchases from users I recommend to. If you see the value in adding some of the additional stuff, that would also be very cool.

Merci :)
{quote}

Originally http://sourcetree.tenderapp.com/discussions/suggestions/181-custom-external-actions
fields.summary: Custom actions from log / files

fields.description: Pretty rare, but would be nice to be able to handle it. Need to change the way repo's are keyed in order for this to work.
fields.summary: Handle git and hg repo in the same folder
